question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
Let $\mathbf{R}$ be the matrix for reflecting over the vector $\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 5 \end{pmatrix}.$  Find $\det \mathbf{R}.$
inference:
Let $\mathbf{v} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 5 \end{pmatrix}$.  The reflection over the vector $\mathbf{v}$ is given by
$$ \mathbf{R} \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix} - 2 \operatorname{proj}_{\mathbf{v}} \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix}. $$The projection of $\begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix}$ onto $\mathbf{v}$ is
$$ \operatorname{proj}_{\mathbf{v}} \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix} = \frac{\begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 5 \end{pmatrix}}{\|\mathbf{v}\|^2} \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 5 \end{pmatrix} = \frac{x+5y}{1+25} \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 5 \end{pmatrix} = \frac{x+5y}{26} \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 5 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} (x+5y)/26 \\ 5(x+5y)/26 \end{pmatrix}. $$Then
\begin{align*} \mathbf{R} \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix} &= \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix} - 2 \frac{x+5y}{26} \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 5 \end{pmatrix} \\ &= \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} (x+5y)/13 \\ 5(x+5y)/13 \end{pmatrix} \\ &= \begin{pmatrix} 12x/13 - 5y/13 \\ -5x/13 + 12y/13 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 12x-5y \\ -5x+12y \end{pmatrix} / 13. \end{align*}Thus,
$$ \mathbf{R} = \frac{1}{13} \begin{pmatrix} 12 & -5 \\ -5 & 12 \end{pmatrix}. $$Then $\det \mathbf{R} = \frac{1}{13^2} \det \begin{pmatrix} 12 & -5 \\ -5 & 12 \end{pmatrix} = \frac{1}{169} (12 \cdot 12 - (-5)(-5)) = \frac{144-25}{169} = \frac{119}{169}.$

Final Answer: $\boxed{\frac{119}{169}}$
ground_truth:
A reflection matrix is always of the form
\[\begin{pmatrix} \cos 2 \theta & \sin 2 \theta \\ \sin 2 \theta & -\cos 2 \theta \end{pmatrix},\]where the vector being reflected over has direction vector $\begin{pmatrix} \cos \theta \\ \sin \theta \end{pmatrix}.$  The determinant of this matrix is then
\[(\cos 2 \theta)(-\cos 2 \theta) - \sin^2 2 \theta = -\cos^2 2 \theta - \sin^2 2 \theta = \boxed{-1}.\](Why does this make sense geometrically?)

$$ \mathbf{R} \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix} - 2 \operatorname{proj}_{\mathbf{v}} \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix}. $$The projection of $\begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix}$ onto $\mathbf{v}$ is
$$ \operatorname{proj}_{\mathbf{v}} \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix} = \frac{\begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 5 \end{pmatrix}}{\|\mathbf{v}\|^2} \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 5 \end{pmatrix} = \frac{x+5y}{1^2+5^2} \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 5 \end{pmatrix} = \frac{x+5y}{26} \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 5 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} (x+5y)/26 \\ 5(x+5y)/26 \end{pmatrix}. $$Then
\begin{align*} \mathbf{R} \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix} &= \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix} - 2 \frac{x+5y}{26} \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 5 \end{pmatrix} \\ &= \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} (x+5y)/13 \\ 5(x+5y)/13 \end{pmatrix} \\ &= \begin{pmatrix} x - (x+5y)/13 \\ y - 5(x+5y)/13 \end{pmatrix} \\ &= \begin{pmatrix} (13x - x - 5y)/13 \\ (13y - 5x - 25y)/13 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 12x - 5y \\ -5x + 12y \end{pmatrix} / 13. \end{align*}Thus,
$$ \mathbf{R} = \frac{1}{13} \begin{pmatrix} 12 & -5 \\ -5 & 12 \end{pmatrix}. $$Then $\det \mathbf{R} = \frac{1}{13^2} \det \begin{pmatrix} 12 & -5 \\ -5 & 12 \end{pmatrix} = \frac{1}{169} (12 \cdot 12 - (-5)(-5)) = \frac{144-25}{169} = \frac{119}{169}.$

Final Answer: $\boxed{\frac{119}{169}}$
